Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CEDAR--Observational and Numerical Studies of Tide-planetary Wave Coupling
Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this project is to delineate and understand variability in the mesosphere-lower thermosphere due to the interaction of atmospheric tides and planetary waves. The approach is to employ temperature measurements from the TIMED and EOS satellites, data recorded by ground-based wind radars, and an observation-driven, nonlinear mechanistic model. Satellite data will be used to diagnose planetary waves and to recover the spectrum of diurnal tides. Global tidal winds will be computed from the observed temperature tides, and synthesized at longitudes and latitudes of individual radars. A comparative analysis with the radar data will then be used to validate the global tidal winds and to illuminate the extent to which local temporal variations can be attributed to global-scale influences including cross-hemisphere coupling. The underlying mechanisms and origins of tide-planetary wave interaction, including forcing terms, relative importance compared to other tidal sources and the role of atmospheric background conditions will be diagnosed from various model runs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to present observational support
for tide-planetary wave (PW) interaction as a source of nonmigrating diurnal tides during wintertime months. Interest in this process stems from observations that suggest enhanced tidal response in  ionospheric parameters following sudden stratospheric warmings.

Our approach consisted of 1. Extracting short-term definitions of planetary waves (PWs) and diurnal tides from satellite data and the Navy's high-altitude numerical weather prediction model (NOGAPS ALPHA)  analyses; 2. Using these diagnostics to compute (nonlinear) forcing terms arising from advection of PW 1 momentum by the migrating diurnal tide (DW1), and of tidal momentum by PW 1, and 3. Examining the response of a primitive equation model to the observation-driven nonlinear forcing (item 2).

Figure 1 demonstrates the apparent connection between PW 1 amplitude (top), zonal mean temperature (second), zonal mean wind (third) and ampltude of the diurnal westward wavenumber 2 tide (DW2), predicted to arise from tide-PW coupling. Note how the amplitude of DW2 tracks the PW 1 amplitude. Note also the occurrence of warm stratospheric temperatures following the breakdown of the PW 1 amplitude, and the occurrence of westward winds following the warming.

The apparent association between DW2 and PW 1 appears during all winter seasons available from NOGAPS ALPHA (Jan-Ferbruary 2005, 2006, 2008, 2009, 2010, and Augist-September-October 2009). However, DW2 has additional sources besides nonlinear interaction. In order to confirm that this process is indeed a source of DW2, it is necessary to examine the response of a tidal model to nonlinear forcing only. This was carried out by forcing  David Ortland's primitive equation model with tide-PW advective terms computed from the actual tidal and PW diagnostics from NOGAPS ALPHA.

Figure 2 shows the results of a calculation spanning December 2009-February 2010. In early December the amplitude of PW 1 geopotential  (top panel) was very strong. Accompanying this development was a significantly enhanced DW2 (third panel). Although DW1 (second panel) was not particularly strong, the interaction between DW1 and PW1 produced a DW2 (bottom panel) that coincides with the observed DW2 in early December. The secondary maxima in DW2 in late December and January appear to evolve in a similar way. In late February, PW 1 is weak but DW1 is quite strong, resulting in a modeled DW2 response that matched the observed.

The modeling experiments for all available winter seasons mimic to various degrees the behavior showcased in Figure 2. Our work is the first known observation-driven effort to model and validate DW1-PW1 tide interaction. We conclude that this process is responsible for the short term variability of DW2 during the winter months we observed,  and is indeed an efficient mechanism for nonmigrating diurnal tide generation and vertical transmission.

Our findings will impact the development of space weather modeling and prediction during quiet solar conditions. This project validated and utilized a prototype high-altitude numerical weather prediction - data assimilation system (NOGAPS ALPHA). Our work also highlights the importance of providing forecasts at intervals greater than 6 hours, owing to the importance of the semidiurnal tide at high altitudes and latitudes. This information can guide sampling considerations for future satellite mission planning,  The results of our study also provide clear guidelines for interpreting tidal variability at a single site during strong wintertime planetary wave episodes.

This project trained undergraduate and graduate students at Clemson University.
